NikeNike The world‚Äôs best athletes aren't just motivated by the idea of winning ‚Äî they are relentlessly fueled by it. That mindset is on display in Nike‚Äôs summer 2024 campaign, ‚ÄúWinning Isn‚Äôt for Everyone.‚Äù Nike and a collective of its elite athletes are showing the world what passion for winning means, and that celebrating the pursuit of victory can be the ultimate source of inspiration for all athletes.Learn more about the campaign: https://lnkd.in/gQaHbFKmhashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#WinningIsntForEveryone youtube.com

NikeNike "The thing I remember most about Rafa is the expression on his face when he‚Äôd get down ‚Äî he‚Äôd twist his mouth and his eyes would narrow, and you would say to yourself, ‚ÄòOh, look out, he‚Äôs put his game face on,‚Äô‚Äù says our co-founder¬†& Chairman Emeritus, Phil Knight. ‚ÄúYou could¬†always¬†see that tenacity. When he hit a forehand, the ball changed shape, he‚Äôd hit it so hard. And¬†no one was going to outlast him in a five-set match. He was always fun to watch, and he was never out of a match.‚ÄùVamos forever, Rafa.See more on how we‚Äôre celebrating the career of one of tennis‚Äô all-time greats: https://lnkd.in/g_tefwEJhashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#NikeTennis

NikeNike Hello, 2025. Let's get to work. üí™  Relentless determination and hunger for a challenge is the ethos behind Nike‚Äôs Year of the Mamba collection. Featuring Kobe Protro models V, VI and IX, the collection is designed with the obsessive attention to detail that was the cornerstone to Kobe Bryant‚Äôs career. Kobe product is synonymous with putting in the work while everyone else rests. When a shoe is linked to a mindset, says Bronson Yim, Kobe Footwear Product Line Manager, you have a product that stands the test of time. ‚ÄúA product becomes something more when it draws an emotion out of you,‚Äù says Yim. ‚ÄúWearing Kobe product is about expecting the highest standards for yourself and what you can accomplish. Working on a lineup of Protros like these is a privilege because I get to be part of a team that encourages players to bring Mamba Mentality into their lives, whether they watched him play or not. If a player puts on some Kobes, the question we try to answer is, ‚ÄòWhat should they feel when they lace up and get to work?‚Äô‚Äù Learn more about Nike‚Äôs Year of the Mamba Collection: https://lnkd.in/gXBTad5xhashtag#NikeBasketball hashtag#Kobe hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike ‚ÄúThere are still so many stigmas around motherhood, especially through the lens of sport,‚Äù says Fanny Yung Ho, Nike Senior Manager, Design Innovation.  ‚ÄúOur team asked ourselves, how do we break down those barriers? How do we celebrate motherhood more?‚Äù The answer: the Nike (M) Swoosh Bra ‚Äî the brand‚Äôs first nursing sports bra that‚Äôs compatible with wearable breast pumps, allowing mothers to unlock movement without compromising comfort or support. The bra has proprietary Nike hardware that helps ensure the clips stand up to lunges and burpees while pumping, along with offering easy access for nursing and adjustability for up to two full cup sizes. ‚ÄúWith this bra, we want to empower women to say, ‚ÄòHere I am ‚Äî I‚Äôm pumping, I‚Äôm moving, I‚Äôm proud to be a mom, I‚Äôm proud to be an athlete, and I can be both at the same time,'‚Äù says Ho. Check out all the features of the Nike (M) Swoosh Bra: https://lnkd.in/gRRJkbUVAnd learn how Ho and the Nike innovation team pulled off designing the bra during the height of the pandemic: https://lnkd.in/gSmfdchK hashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#MothersDay

NikeNike The defining athlete of the year ‚Äî and no doubt years to come. Congratulations to TIME Magazine‚Äôs 2024 Athlete of the Year, Caitlin Clark, who inspired and invigorated communities in and out of sport. ‚ÄúWith her incredible athleticism, focus and determination, Caitlin has evolved the sports conversation from a binary women and men‚Äôs dynamic to a celebration of basketball and what makes it great, reminding us all why we love the game,‚Äù says Amy Melczer Montagne, VP/GM Nike Women, who gathered with Nike teammates and athletes at the TIME gala in New York City to honor Caitlin. ‚ÄúWitnessing this pivotal moment, here with our Nike¬†team, is a reminder of the singular experiences of working at this brand and the unmatched energy they give you.‚Äù Get more behind-the scenes looks and interviews with our Nike athletes: https://about.nike.com/en/ hashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#NikeBasketball

NikeNike Too often, when breastfeeding moms return to work, they find themselves pumping in spaces that feel like an afterthought.¬†For¬†Nike, working moms¬†are¬†a priority.¬†It‚Äôs why, at our¬†European Logistics Campus (ELC) in Belgium,¬†we‚Äôve reimagined our mothers‚Äô rooms with thoughtful renovations¬†to¬†create¬†calm, comfortable spaces where nursing moms feel fully supported.  ‚ÄúAs a breastfeeding mom myself, this has been empowering in so many ways,‚Äù says Nike employee Kaat Clerix, who led the¬†renovation¬†project. ‚ÄúThese rooms make work-life integration more feasible. They‚Äôve helped me be successful in both my personal and professional life. It feels inclusive and fosters my sense of belonging.‚Äù Purposefully designed with comfortable furniture, a wash sink, relaxing music, towels, a fridge for milk storage ‚Äî there‚Äôs even a spot to hang birth announcements ‚Äî these spaces¬†are built to¬†help working¬†moms¬†feel cared for and empowered. ‚ÄúBecoming a mom is one of the most life-changing events a woman will experience,‚Äù Clerix says. ‚ÄúWhen your employer shows awareness and investment in your well-being as a mom, it makes you feel respected and supported. It gives you the energy to go the extra mile in your work.‚Äù Check out more ways Nike supports working moms: https://lnkd.in/g96aWybT hashtag#NikeCareers, hashtag#SwooshLife, hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike Take the everyday backpack, and make it easier to use for all athletes, no matter their physical ability. That was the brief for Nike Lead Equipment Designer Brent Radewald and his teammates ahead of Paris this summer. The end result is the Nike Elite EasyOn Backpack, a Paralympic innovation that‚Äôs now available on Nike.com. Now, every athlete can experience the benefits of a more intuitive backpack. That‚Äôs universal design in a nutshell, says Radewald, and it‚Äôs one of his most satisfying responsibilities in his creative career at Nike.‚ÄúUniversal design helps all athletes perform at their best,‚Äù says Radewald. ‚ÄúIf we create a better bag for our adaptive athletes, we create a better product for every athlete.‚ÄùLearn more about the Nike Elite EasyOn Backpack at https://lnkd.in/gA2AfGBEhashtag#NikeDesign hashtag#NikeEasyOn hashtag#Disability

NikeNike At Nike‚Äôs Air Manufacturing Innovation facilities¬†(Air MI), highly skilled teams build the proprietary Air units that power our most iconic shoes.Four¬†work shifts run around the clock,¬†and¬†every operator¬†contributes to the shoes¬†that¬†end¬†up on the¬†feet of elite¬†and everyday¬†athletes.‚Äú(It) gives you a sense of pride to know that you were part of that process,‚Äù says production manager Cassie Rigles-Kocker.Take a behind-the-scenes look at the places where Nike Air and other breakthrough innovations are made:https://lnkd.in/gMr7-gNwhashtag#NikeInnovation hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#AirMI hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike The disability experience is the human experience.  With that belief, we‚Äôre celebrating Global Accessibility Awareness Day with our Accessibility Center of Excellence and the Employee Disability Network proudly co-hosting our second annual¬†Accessibility¬†Summit, a two-day event on Nike‚Äôs World Headquarters campus in Beaverton, Ore.At NIKE, Inc., the Accessibility Summit provides opportunity and space to build community, support teammates and demonstrate how accessibility has been and will continue to be a sharp point of innovation in product and in the employee experience. ‚ÄúNike‚Äôs culture of innovation is fueled by curiosity and gaining insights from a diverse disability perspective to create the future of access to sport, fashion and self-expression for all," says Megan Lawrence, PhD, Sr. Director of Global Accessibility and the host for the summit.¬†‚ÄúNike is a company that values diverse ways of thinking and new ideas to drive innovation through the lens of inclusion.‚ÄùLearn more about what that means for us: https://lnkd.in/dpWnGc33hashtag#GlobalAccessibilityAwarenessDay hashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#LifeAtNike

NikeNike It was a window into the future. On December 7, more than 400 of the country‚Äôs best distance runners traveled to Portland, Ore., for the Nike Cross Nationals (NXN) Finals. NXN is the pinnacle high school cross-country showcase in the United States, and individual runners and clubs from eight regional championships went head to head, leaving it all on the course to be crowned National Champion. Many of the top finishers of NXN grow into accomplished¬†pro runners, winning national championships, international medals ‚Äî even Olympic gold. In the middle of the action that weekend was Cameron ‚ÄúCam‚Äù Yates, Brand Manager, North America, Nike Running. He says that his team gets to ‚Äúbring high school running to life in the United States,‚Äù and they cut no corners in making NXN the most thrilling race experience possible for the competitors, right down to the color of the course markers and the graphic treatment of the finish line. ‚ÄúI found running later in my life,‚Äù says Cam, who grew up playing baseball and soccer. ‚ÄúAfter putting on meets like this, I get to see how supportive the running community is toward each other. You especially see that during NXN, with how the pros travel here on race day to encourage the high school runners. For these high school kids, a big part of their experience is shaped by seeing these accomplished runners who they admire, and who‚Äôve competed in this race themselves, cheering them on. They‚Äôll remember it for the rest of their lives. It‚Äôs inspiring to me that I get to help create an experience like this.‚ÄùCheck out more behind-the-scenes photos from race day: https://lnkd.in/gGbNJeRhhashtag#NikeRunning hashtag#NXN2024 hashtag#NikeCrossNationals

NikeNike At the LeBron James Innovation Center, more than 80 cutting-edge machines help bring breakthrough designs to life ‚Äî including this one which heat-forms shoes to match an athlete‚Äôs foot and create a perfectly performing fit.‚ÄúThe LeBron James building is this entire machine and the athlete is just that moment of contact between the hot heel former and the shoe itself,‚Äù says Noah Murphy-Reinhertz, Senior Director, Sustainable Product Design. ‚ÄúIt takes all this other work, all these other people, all this other investigation and innovation to make that moment happen. Also, it just looks really cool. It‚Äôs like a wild robot.‚ÄùThe heel-counter and shoe-lasting machine is just one of the many elements of wonder at the LeBron James Innovation Center, a place that‚Äôs been described as the Willy Wonka factory for innovation. Step behind the curtain to discover more of the spaces where we help athletes be the fastest, strongest and greatest they can be: https://lnkd.in/gMr7-gNwhashtag#NikeInnovation hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#LeBronJames hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike This year, Nike‚Äôs Air Max Night in Shanghai wasn‚Äôt just a celebration. It was a full-blown creative takeover.During one unforgettable night, a corner of the city‚Äôs pulsing West Bund district became home to a glowing, inflatable Innovation Lab featuring eight surreal walk-through zones designed to bring the spirit of Nike‚Äôs new Air Max DN8 to life.At the center of it all: global pop icon and formally world-ranked fencer Jackson Wang, who served as creative curator. Wang shaped the immersive¬†‚ÄúFootstep in Shanghai‚Äù¬†experience ‚Äî a journey through culture, music and movement that captured the DN8‚Äôs energy through his own visionary lens.The Shanghai experience was part of a larger wave of bold activations across Greater China. From Beijing to Chengdu to Guangzhou, each city brought its own energy, all united by the fearless experimentation that‚Äôs defined Air Max from the start.Sport energy like that is part of Wang's DNA ‚Äî his mom was a national team gymnast and his dad fenced for China. Dive into more of his backstory and journey to join the NIKE, Inc. family: https://lnkd.in/g7gcGK5uhashtag#AirMaxNight hashtag#JacksonWang hashtag#NikeInnovation hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike Marisa Smith started at Nike as a seasonal retail employee. Last week, she stood on a much bigger stage ‚Äî emceeing the Women of Nike (WON) Fashion Show at Nike World Headquarters.Her journey from a retail store associate to a Nike EKIN ‚Äî that‚Äôs Nike spelled backward, because these brand storytellers know the company backward and forward ‚Äî wasn‚Äôt a straight path. The Texas native worked at five different stores before taking a leap with Nike‚Äôs¬†Track Stretch Program, a six-month initiative that gives retail employees the opportunity to work at WHQ. Following that, she landed a permanent role training store teams in Dallas.No matter where she‚Äôs been, one thing has stayed the same: the power of the Nike community.‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt be here today if it weren‚Äôt for the people ‚Äî my mentors, my teammates, the leaders who reminded me to keep going when things got tough,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the magic of Nike. We push each other forward.‚ÄùThat same energy was on¬†display as she took the mic at the WON show, calling out names while women of all backgrounds, body types and career paths took the stage. Together, they celebrated identity, empowerment and growth ‚Äî¬†a message that resonates deeply with Smith.‚ÄúThis wasn‚Äôt just about fashion,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt was about celebrating who we are, where we‚Äôve come from and where we‚Äôre going.‚ÄùThe show‚Äôs theme ‚Äî honoring your legacy and blooming into who you‚Äôre meant to be ‚Äî felt personal to her.‚ÄúWhen I started in retail, I was just looking for a job to get me through college; I never imagined it would turn into this. As soon as I saw last year‚Äôs show, I knew I had to be a part of it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThe energy was just unmatched. The women. The atmosphere. The celebration of our stories. It‚Äôs why I love working here.‚ÄùThe excitement reminded her of the first time she visited WHQ.‚ÄúThe moment I stepped on campus for the first time, I knew ‚Äî this is where I belong.‚ÄùLearn more about Nike‚Äôs¬†Track Stretch Program: https://lnkd.in/gcUcRgQbhashtag#WomenOfNike hashtag#WONFashionShow hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#JustDoItPC: Dascha O., Aeri Kim, Mike Esparza, Pauline Zonneveld and Nelly M. Tonleu

NikeNike ‚ÄúNike doesn‚Äôt just show up to serve a market. We‚Äôre leaning into culture and doing it authentically.‚ÄùThat‚Äôs Camila Snider, Lead Resilience and Portfolio Manager at Nike and one of many teammates who attended Experience Velocity 2024, which took place last week in beautiful San Diego, California. The business conference highlights the economic influence of the nation‚Äôs Latino population, giving attendees the chance to connect with the broader Latino talent community. Nike‚Äôs presence at L‚ÄôATTITUDE made a big impression on Camila. As co-chair of Nike‚Äôs Latino and Friends Employee Network, she helps invite teammates across the company to engage with, learn from and better understand Latino culture. Showing up at L‚ÄôATTITUDE, she says, reflects the company‚Äôs values to be at the forefront of these community-led events and conferences.For Camila, one of the event‚Äôs highlights was hearing from Doug Bowles, Nike VP/GM of Nike LatAm, who was one of L‚ÄôATTITUDE‚Äôs keynote speakers. Bowles used the brand‚Äôs recent marathon campaign in Mexico City as a case study for Nike‚Äôs investment to serve runners across Latin America. ‚ÄúWhen he was talking about the energy and excitement around running in Mexico City, I got chills,‚Äù says Camila. ‚ÄúIt made me feel so inspired and connected to the brand. It‚Äôs one reason why I say with pride and joy that I‚Äôm a Nike employee ‚Äî We get to authentically serve markets all over the world.‚ÄùLearn more about our employee networks at https://lnkd.in/dpWnGc33hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#LATTITUDE2024

NikeNike She wouldn‚Äôt be denied. British runner Keely Hodgkinson won her first gold in the 800 meter in dominant fashion, winning in 1:56.72. ‚ÄúI have so many silvers, what drives me now is the will to win, the will to one day say, ‚ÄòI am the best,‚Äô‚Äù says the 22-year-old. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs a great achievement, and I‚Äôve worked really hard to fulfill it.‚ÄùKeely ran the fastest time in the half mile this year when she clocked in a blistering 1:54.61 back in July, which made her the sixth-fastest woman over the distance in history. Now, Keely can add another title to the history books: Olympic champion. Check out all the stories on our inspiring Nike athletes here: https://lnkd.in/gpcCTSuehashtag#Paris2024 hashtag#Olympics hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike To serve runners, we‚Äôre not only focused on creating innovative products. We also want to give athletes tools that help them understand *how* they run ‚Äî and how to run better. That‚Äôs why our Nike Sport Research Lab created NSRL Form, a two-minute movement-analysis tool. ‚ÄúNSRL Form is the culmination of years of research and listening to runners, with the goal to give every runner the power to know themselves and magnify their running journey ‚Äî whatever that may be,‚Äù says Blaise Williams, Principal Sport Scientist at the NSRL. ‚ÄúThe team that created Form had the most intelligent and innovative scientists, engineers, creatives and leaders that the sports science world has to offer. Runners, know that this tool can help you be your best because it was created by the best.‚Äù Check out how NSRL Form works and where you can try it out: https://lnkd.in/g9yfa2c6 hashtag#NikeRunning hashtag#Innovation hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike Did you see that final trick from Nike athlete Yuto Horigome? üëÄ The 25-year-old Japanese skateboarder took home his second Olympic gold medal in men‚Äôs street skateboarding today after landing a nollie 270 noseblunt slide.‚ÄúIn skateboarding, there is no right or wrong; but I can‚Äôt help but search for what the right thing to do is. I don‚Äôt think there is an answer,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut when I have faith in myself, I think I‚Äôll be able to achieve my dreams. Having trust in yourself is the most important thing ‚Äî having the confidence to believe in yourself."Check out all the stories on our inspiring Nike athletes here: https://lnkd.in/gfSdageahashtag#Paris2024 hashtag#Olympics hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike As a young girl attending a Native American boarding school on the Cherokee Nation Reservation in Oklahoma, Dr.Christine Panther remembers being taught the cultural practice of rising before dawn to greet the sun. That daily reverence toward the natural world helped inspire Panther, whose origins trace back to Oklahoma‚Äôs Kiowa, Quapaw and Shawnee Nations, to take up running throughout high school and into her adulthood. Many Indigenous communities across the world share the same sentiment: Nature can be a conduit to movement, which, in turn, is a conduit for change. ‚ÄúIndigenous communities across the world honor nature through movement and sport,‚Äù says Panther, a Sr. Manager, Social & Community Impact (SCI) at Nike. ‚ÄúSport is medicine. Sport opens up a world of possibilities outside our door, especially for our young people. That‚Äôs why the N7 Fund‚Äôs connection to movement and sport is so vital, and so transformative.‚Äù Among Panther‚Äôs responsibilities within SCI is to help facilitate the N7 Fund application process, which is now open through January 6. The program recognizes nonprofits¬†at all scales, from grassroots to the national level, that¬†are increasing access to sport for Indigenous youth across North America. Watching these groups use the power of sport to change lives for the better is a privilege, says Panther. Her work at Nike, she says, places her within a proud lineage of¬†Indigenous leaders and¬†organizations, past and present, who see movement as a pathway toward transformation.  ‚ÄúThe N7 Fund follows the proverbial wisdom of Indigenous communities to consider the impact of our choices on the seventh generation,‚Äù says Panther. ‚ÄúThe children from this and future generations are benefitting from the tireless work of our partners, which the fund helps support. Getting a front-row seat to see how they will change the world is an honor.‚Äù Learn more about the N7 Fund and apply at https://lnkd.in/g-BSm_4Bhashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#NikeN7Fund hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike Did you see that breakaway?! Nike athlete Sifan Hassan claimed gold today in the women‚Äôs marathon, clocking a time of¬†2:22:55, separating herself from a pack of three in the last minutes of the race.The medal was her third of the Paris Games, as she secured bronze in the 5,000 meter on August 5 and 10,000 meter on August 9. She is the first athlete to complete this triple feat since Czech runner Emil Z√°topek swept gold in the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki.‚ÄúWhen running, sometimes I feel good‚Ä¶and sometimes I feel bad and feel like I can‚Äôt continue,‚Äù says the 31-year-old Dutch athlete. ‚ÄúLife is the same way, and that‚Äôs what makes life beautiful, the way it goes up and down.‚Äù As of late July, the versatile runner ranked as the 22nd-fastest woman in the 1,500 meter, seventh-fastest in the 5,000 meter, ninth-fastest in the 10,000 meter¬†and second-fastest in the marathon.In 2021, she became the only athlete in Olympic history to medal in the 1,500, 5,000 and 10,000 meter events at the same Olympics Games. Last fall, Sifan won the 2023 Chicago Marathon ‚Äî and achieved the second-fastest women‚Äôs marathon finish of all time ‚Äî in 2:13:44.Check out all the stories on our inspiring Nike athletes here: https://lnkd.in/gfSdageahashtag#Paris2024 hashtag#Olympics hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike When Christopher Hicks was in the first grade, he had zero interest in playing baseball.But one persistent voice ‚Äî Coach Walter at the local Boys & Girls Club ‚Äî convinced him to step onto the diamond anyway, igniting a lifelong love for sport.Now, many years later, he‚Äôs giving back in the same way his coach did. As Senior Manager on Nike‚Äôs Social & Community Impact team, Chris helps power programs like the Nike Mamba League, giving kids from underserved LA communities the chance to learn, grow and thrive through basketball.Hicks‚Äô love for basketball started early. ‚ÄúGrowing up, sport was a safe space where I could be free,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBasketball gave me comfort, security and confidence, allowing me to push my own limits and unlock my potential.‚ÄùAfter college, Hicks coached at the Kobe Bryant Basketball Academy where he saw firsthand how impactful the ‚ÄúMamba Mentality‚Äù was for kids. Those experiences set him up for an incredible full-circle moment nearly 10 years later during his first Nike project: expanding the Mamba League throughout Los Angeles. And on his initial site visit to the Boys & Girls Club of Wilmington, guess who opened the door? Coach Walter, still supporting local youth as the club‚Äôs transportation director.‚ÄúI recognized him immediately,‚Äù Hicks says. ‚ÄúSeeing his continued commitment to the community after all these years was inspiring.‚ÄùLike Coach Walter‚Äôs dedication, the Mamba League is rooted in Kobe‚Äôs vision: empowering young athletes through inclusive coaching, equal playing time, age-appropriate equipment and at least 50% girls participation.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what it‚Äôs all about for me,‚Äù Hicks says. ‚ÄúThrough Mamba League, we get to spark joy for kids across L.A. and keep them in the game.‚ÄùRead more about how Nike is powering the future of youth sport: https://lnkd.in/gSXe6AsChashtag#MambaLeague hashtag#NikeImpact hashtag#FutureOfSport hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike Nike‚Äôs employee-led networks are built on the diverse, intersecting identities of all our teammates. This month, Paralympian Beatriz Hatz visited Nike‚Äôs World Headquarters and sat down with members from two employee networks ‚Äî the Disability Network and the Latino & Friends Network ‚Äî to share more about her overlapping identities as a multi-ethnic, disabled athlete. Erica Korpi, a Senior Administrative Assistant at Nike, serves on the leadership team for Nike‚Äôs Disability Network, and was one of the moderators who sat down with Beatriz for a heartfelt conversation about the athlete's career, her summer in Paris, and her intersectional identities. Beatriz‚Äôs personal story hits home for Erica. ‚ÄúI consider myself both a runner and a disabled woman,‚Äù says Erica. ‚ÄúConnecting with others like me, especially someone as incredible as Beatriz, feeds my soul. Nike‚Äôs core belief ‚Äî 'If you have a body, you‚Äôre an athlete' ‚Äî is brought to life through visits like these. It was an honor to share her story with our Nike teammates.‚Äù Learn more about our Nike United Networks: https://lnkd.in/gcxyit3Shashtag#LifeAtNike hashtag#DEAM hashtag#HispanicHeritageMonth hashtag#NikeUNITED

NikeNike As Nike‚Äôs longest-tenured employee on the Social & Community Impact team ‚Äî 47 years with the Swoosh and counting!¬†‚Äî Kathy Webb,¬†Nike Employee Community Engagement Director, knows a thing or two about legacy. In 2007, she¬†and her team established a long-time partnership with Special Olympics Oregon (SOOR), creating the Nike Youth Games which invited kids with intellectual disabilities to world headquarters to experience a team sport for the first time. ‚ÄúThis never-been-done-before youth event brought potential Oregon Special Olympics athletes and their families face-to-face with SOOR staff and Nike volunteers where they learned the basics of track, soccer, bocce¬†and basketball ‚Äî¬†a first step into SOOR‚Äôs youth sports programs,‚Äù Webb says. And it worked. Sixteen years later, SOOR has achieved its goal of building statewide awareness of its youth programs and creating a pipeline of youth participants ready to benefit from its sports programs.¬†Now, they‚Äôve asked Nike to help them tackle a new goal, one that happens to coincide with the next phase of life for many of SOOR‚Äôs youth participants ‚Äî high school. Nike¬†is making a¬†three-year, $300,000 investment that will¬†expand SOOR‚Äôs Unified Sports¬Æ Program, which pairs Special Olympics athletes and partners as teammates for training and competition.¬†Together, SOOR and Nike will co-host coaching clinics for basketball, soccer¬†and track & field at Nike‚Äôs world headquarters, open to both the community and Nike employee volunteers. The first basketball clinic was held last month, with more planned for spring. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs simply no better partner to make sure kids with intellectual disabilities have the access and quality coaching they deserve as they unite in play with their peers,‚Äù says Webb. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what SOOR calls ‚Äòinclusion revolution,‚Äô and it brings out the best in all of us.‚Äù Check out more ways we support programs like SOOR: https://lnkd.in/gZSvXqqhhashtag#NikeCommunityImpact, hashtag#SpecialOlympics, hashtag#UnifiedSports, hashtag#JustDoIt

NikeNike When Nike‚Äôs employee networks mobilize around a cause, they create change that ripples from the inside out.That concept is nothing new for Taya Saxton, a Director of Cross Functional Sustainability at Nike. Taya served over four years in the Air Force, and she‚Äôs worked at Nike for almost a decade now, helping lead the company‚Äôs supply chain strategy to become more environmentally responsible. As a member of the leadership team on Nike‚Äôs Military Veterans and Friends Network (NMV), Saxton and her colleagues saw another opportunity to spearhead: helping shape a paid leave program for Nike‚Äôs military employees.‚ÄúA consistent trait among our military friends is the resolve to find a way, even if you don‚Äôt know something,‚Äù says Taya. ‚ÄúWhen I was on active duty in the Air Force, I was immediately placed in an aerospace program. I knew nothing about satellites. But I didn‚Äôt have another option. I needed to hunker down and start learning. You find that commitment inside of every Nike military veteran.‚ÄùThe network drafted a detailed proposal for the leave program in 2017, eventually presenting to the company‚Äôs senior leadership. The support was resounding. A year later, Nike introduced its military leave program, giving employees who volunteer or are called back to the uniformed services up to 12 weeks of paid time off every 12 months.‚ÄúThe NMV really helped champion the program,‚Äù says Taya. ‚ÄúI love how our network gets to focus on showing up for the Nike military community at large, in addition to representing the military experience for all of our employees.‚ÄùLearn more about how Nike supports the personal and professional well-being of our employees: https://lnkd.in/dpWnGc33hashtag#MemorialDay hashtag#NikeUnited hashtag#NMV hashtag#SwooshLife

That kind of spirit is part of what makes Nike such a great place to work.‚ÄùCongrats to winners JeongEun Han in Daejeon, South Korea; Manuela Cardenas Negre in Mallorca, Spain; Zijun Wu in Guangzhou, China; and Rodrigo Ceballos in West Jordan, Utah.You too can look fly ‚Äî shop Air Max now: https://lnkd.in/gPZFvzwyhashtag#AirMaxDay hashtag#NikeAirMax hashtag#NikeRetail

NikeNike Congrats to Alexis Hanquinquant on his dominating Paratriathlon win yesterday ‚Äî the Nike athlete took his second consecutive gold in the Men‚Äôs PTS4 race, clocking in at 58:01, nearly three minutes ahead of the silver medal finisher. A six-time world champion, Hanquinquant was also the flag-bearer for France at this year‚Äôs Paralympics."I don't really have a disability, I have a difference,‚Äù says the 38-year-old. ‚ÄúWeare often seen as people with disabilities who play sports, when in fact we arehigh-level athletes with a difference.‚ÄùWith his legendary performances, Hanquinquant has become a PTS4 icon, a class reserved for triathletes with absence of limbs or whose coordination is affected at a high degree in one arm or at a low-level on one of their sides. During the running and cycling portions of the event, athletes are allowed to use approved prostheses or supportive devices.Prior to the Games, Hanquinquant was thrilled about the prospect of winning back-to-back golds on home soil. ‚ÄúThe real feat is to repeat the feat. Again and again,‚Äù he says. With his win in Paris, Hanquinquant has done exactly that.Check out all the stories on our inspiring Nike athletes here: https://lnkd.in/gfSdageahashtag#Paris2024 hashtag#Paralymipcs hashtag#WinnningIsWinning

NikeNike At Nike, community is an open invitation. Our eight NikeUNITED employee-led networks are a huge part of that, and invite in all teammates, whether or not they directly identify with the network‚Äôs background. This month, Nike‚Äôs Ascend Network is organizing a packed week at our World Headquarters in Beaverton, Ore., including a block party and a cricket clinic, teaching the fundamentals of one of the world‚Äôs most popular sports. The Ascend Network includes teammates with roots in Asia, the Middle East and the Pacific Islands, and any Nike employee can join the celebration. That impact is far reaching. Take it from EJ Kim, a Senior Merchant for Global Men's Running Footwear at Nike, who wants all employees to know they can find a new, supportive community in Ascend. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm grateful to be part of the Ascend Network in a leadership capacity and be able to organize events that celebrate and bring awareness to our diverse cultures,‚Äù says EJ. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had the opportunity to show up as my most authentic self at Nike. Our network encourages and inspires others in our community to do the same.‚Äù Learn more about our employee-led communities: https://lnkd.in/gcxyit3Shashtag#AAPIHM hashtag#NikeUNITED hashtag#Ascend hashtag#SwooshLife

NikeNike Growing up in a single-parent, immigrant household, Zainee Gafoor didn‚Äôt have access to a lot of sport- and play-based programs, or the lifelong benefits she knows would have come along with them.  Now, as a mom of two young kids and a Retail Operations Manager supporting Nike-owned stores throughout Canada, she‚Äôs determined to help expand sport for the next generation and give all kids, including her own, an opportunity to play.  ‚ÄúIf we think about our mission statement of bringing inspiration and innovation to every athlete, that has to include the young and emerging athletes, and it has to include young and emerging athletes who are underserved,‚Äù says Zainee, a 13-year Nike employee, who also serves on the leadership committee for Nike‚Äôs ASCEND Network.  So when the opportunity to join Toronto‚Äôs Nike Community Impact Fund (NCIF) Employee Grant Selection Committee arose, Zainee jumped at the chance. The NCIF program trains each committee member on how to assess grant applications, so they can then share their local insights to decide which community organizations should receive funding.  ‚ÄúJust knowing we can make a real impact on our community as individuals and as an organization is so rewarding,‚Äù says Zainee. ‚ÄúAnd being part of the NCIF grant selection process allowed me to learn about different local organizations and the work they do.‚Äù  One that really stood out to her was Trails Youth Initiatives, which was ultimately selected for a grant. ‚ÄúI like that it brings kids to outdoor spaces, opening them up to experiences in nature like hiking or snowshoeing ‚Äî and showing them that there‚Äôs so much more out in the world to see.‚Äù  Check out our most recent NCIF grant recipients in Toronto and across the U.S., Canada, Europe and Japan: https://lnkd.in/eFqiD3YVhashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#SwooshLife hashtag#NikeCommunityImpactFund

NikeNike Oksana Masters is a force ü•á ü•á The Nike athlete clinched her second gold medal of the 2024 Paralympics with a win in the Women's Road Race H5 and a time of 1:52:14 for the 56.8km para-cycling course.This is Oksana's 19th Paralympic medal ‚Äî after notching a gold in the para-cycling women‚Äôs individual time trial on Wednesday ‚Äî and in a range of sports, including para-cross-country skiing, para-biathlon, para-rowing, and now para-cycling. Born with severe leg abnormalties, Oksana made history at the London 2012 Paralympic Games when she became the first American to win a bronze medal in the trunk and arms mixed double sculls event. Oksana is part of Nike‚Äôs Athlete Think Tank, which aims to redefine athlete partnerships and elevate women‚Äôs voices across all levels of sport. Together with athletes like Oksana, Nike aims to drive positive change through sport by investing in the communities and organizations that matter to its athletes.Check out all the stories on our inspiring Nike athletes here: https://lnkd.in/gfSdageahashtag#Paris2024 hashtag#Paralympics hashtag#JustDoIt

Boston shows up no matter what.Nike Run Coach Dan Fitzgerald has seen it all ‚Äî sleet, snow, slush, blazing summer heat ‚Äî and still, the local crews log their miles with grit and heart.As the city gears up for one of its biggest race weekends of the year, the co-founder of Heartbreak Hill Running Company teamed up with Nike to share his favorite spots to run, refuel and recharge.‚ÄúOur job is to connect with running and the running community,‚Äù Fitzgerald says. ‚ÄúI want athletes to show up and just be themselves and be a runner.‚ÄùWhether you're racing this Monday or planning a future trip to the city, this guide has you covered ‚Äî from riverside miles along the Charles River to the climb up Heartbreak Hill, plus local favorites for coffee, grilled cheese and post-run recovery.Read the full guide:https://lnkd.in/gkCDV2KBhashtag#NikeRunning hashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#SwooshLife

NikeNike Here's to the first International Day of Play and finding more ways to get all kids active. Way to go, team üôå hashtag#InternationalDayOfPlay hashtag#JustDoIt hashtag#SwooshLife Vanessa Garcia-BritoVanessa Garcia-Brito I‚Äôm excited to share that we will be celebrating the first ever International Day of Play ‚Äì tomorrow, on June 11 ‚Äì with the UN and the world. Nike, together with other champions for play and sport, helped to make International Day of Play happen. And, we're ready to celebrate! In honor of this special day, Nike will join the other founding partner members, including the UN, Lego Foundation/LEGO Group, Sesame Workshop and others to create a Play space for local elementary school kids and their families at the UN Rose Garden in New York City. We‚Äôre so happy that Nike Trainer Rad Lopez and coaches from PeacePlayers International will also join us to make this a fun and inclusive experience for kids. For ideas on how to spend the day, check out our free coaching resources and learn more about how you can support inclusive, kid-centered play that instills confidence and a sense of belonging in all kids, especially girls: https://lnkd.in/ejSKk4pDYou can learn more about International Day of Play here: https://lnkd.in/e6jRUT-VI would love to hear how you plan to celebrate International Day of Play.
